descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Civil engineering applications of fluid mechanics. Turbulent flow in pipes, pipe networks, and open channels.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prereqs: CHEM_ENG 321; MECH_ENG 241; or consent of instructor

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
1. Describe gas partial pressures and the vapor pressure of water
2. Describe the phenomenological and molecular basis of viscosity
3. Calculate energy transfer during phase changes in water
4. Describe the difference between absolute and gage pressures
5. Compute hydrostatic forces on flat and curved surfaces
6. Apply typical boundary conditions in flow sections and at flow boundaries
7. Apply momentum principles to computation of forces on pipes at pipe bends
8. Compute energy losses in pipes in laminar and turbulent flows
9. Compute energy losses in valves pipe contractions, expansions, and bends
10. Interpret the different terms of the Bernoulli equation
11. Compute energy-head relationships in centrifugal pumps
12. Predict the occurrence of cavitation in pumps and pipe networks
13. Compute flows, pressure and head in branched pipes and pipe networks
14. Compute flow conditions to avoid water hammer
15. Compute uniform flow and critical depths in open channels
16. Develop specific energy equation and concept of the critical state
17. Compute conjugate depths and energy loss in hydraulic jump
18. Classify generic gradually varied flows
19. Compute surface profiles in gradually varied flow (including use of HEC-RAS)
20. Identify and compute critical flows in hydraulic transitions
21. Calculate flow velocity in pipes using pitotubes and hydraulic structures
22. Review/criticize published article on role of water supply in economics of sustainable development
